description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydrometeorological and coastal information for making early warnings and seasonal forecasts which feed into longterm development plans

1 of population with access to improved climate information and flood drought strong winds and coastal warnings disaggregated by gender
2 Development frameworks SCADD PEI that integrate climate information in their formulation of poverty reduction strategies and links between poverty and the environment at the local level Baseline no integration target integration into the revised SCADD and PEI in 2015
3 Sectorspecific EW products and strategies that integrate climate risks agriculture health and cotton production sectors

comment.narrative:
1 There are existing EWS initiatives for regional dam management and famine alerts however a national alert system concerned with extreme hydrometeorological phenomena is lacking There is also a limited understanding of the technical alert jargon alerts are not translated into all national languages There is also no mechanism for endusers most vulnerable populations to be involved in the alert process to ensure its sustainability
Women 5
Men 10
2 Development frameworks do not incorporate any EWSCI products such as risk maps or climate change predictions into longterm planning
3 Sectorspecific strategies do not include EWSCI because the quality of weather forecasts and climate predictions is poor and not tailored for specific uses particularly seasonal forecasts

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of national hydrometeorological services DGMDGRE and environmental institutions DCIME to monitor extreme weather and climate change droughts floods strong winds

1 national coverage for climateweather monitoring
2 Frequency and timeliness of climaterelated data availability

comment.narrative:
1 25 national coverage for climateweather monitoring with respect to the optimal arrangements defined in DGMDGRE feasibility reports and WMO standards 20 synoptic stations 20 agrometeorological stations 8 climate stations 100 rain gauges 71 water level meters and 11 manual flow meters are in place Meteorological stations 142 manual 6 automatic Hydrological stations 82 manual 0 automatic
2 Data from manual weather and hydrological stations is collected monthly and transmitted by post

1 Increase to 75 NHMS optimal monitoring arrangements as defined in the feasibility studies 8 Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers ADCPs for flow measurements 40 automatic climate stations 10 automatic synoptic stations with telemetry and 100 additional rain gauges Meteorological stations 242 manual 56 automatic Hydrological stations 93 manual 8 with telemetry
2 Target for data transmission frequency daily

Indicator 1 national coverage for climateweather monitoring
No progress made as procurement process for climateweather monitoring system is not completed
Following preparatory actions have been undertaken
Technical specifications have been elaborated for the acquisition and installation of meteorological observatory stations
The technical feasibility study that will optimize the hydrometeorological network and its equipment is ongoing The technical mission organized by the regional office provided significant support in the determination of adequate materials which are adapted to countryspecific conditions
Locations for the placement of 50 weather observatory stations have been identified and validated through participatory discussions with local actors The choice of locations takes into account criteria such as the density of the meteorological network in line with WMO standards The data generated from the weather observatory stations will contribute to the improvement of regional data availability Benin Togo Niger Mali Ivory Coast and the increase in weather stations density which will ultimately favor the farmers in the area

No progress made

description.narrative: To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Burkina Faso

1 Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard see Annex 12
2 Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change

comment.narrative:
1 Limited capacity to generate EWS and CI on a national scale for extreme hydrometeorological phenomena Limited disaster risk prevention capacity at local levels within CONASUR No Standard Operating Procedure SOP for alert communication by ANPC with the support of NGOsCSOs
Current score 74
2 Existing budget plans do not have sufficient funds to maintain and operate the environmental monitoring infrastructure

1 Capacity assessment target score 161 for all combined EWS agencies
2 30 increase in domestic financing for equipment operation and maintenance across all institutions

1 Capacity assessment target score 170 for all combined EWS agencies improvement of 9 scores in reference to base line scaore of 161
Followoing actions justifies the improvement of these score
The CONASUR National Council for Disater Risk Mangement organized 3 workshops 141 participants M 120 F 21 The first 2 workshops were organized in the province of Tapoa and Passore The choice of these provinces was oriented by the recurrence of drought episodes in the area and frequent flooding which have resulted in poor yields The strategic choice of the workshop venues contributed to the strengthening of capacity in terms of prevention and risk management The third workshop was held in Koudougou which allowed to activate dialogue with institutions in charge of disseminating climaterelated and meteorological information Discussions have also dealt with the bottleneck of disseminationaccessibility of climate related and meteorological information
The General Direction of Meteorology and General Direction of Water Resource GDWR have initiated the administrative process to recruit 4 engineers as well as 13 technical officers to be trained Their training will allow them to become knowledgeable in the generation analysis management and forecasting of extreme climate and hydrological events The GDWR has identified the training structure for 3 hydrologic and senior hydrologic engineers This capacity development will allow the better management of specific warnings related to hydro and meteorological extreme events
6 partnership agreements have been elaborated and submitted for signature The signature of these conventions will allow different partners to work in synergy and interministerial collaboration in order to achieve project objectives
The programme of SAAGA has taken the action to update the needs for radar rehabilitation since August 2011 The rehabilitation of the radar will increase the efficiency of operations in the search for clouds to provoke rain or the detection of possible droughts
2 No achievement made on the second indicator
